Author: marrone
Content:
agreed.

Also check out 'Pro Javacsript Techniques' by John Resig.

Read this article on closures which is the best description I have read of such a crucial crucial aspect of the language: http://jibbering.com/faq/faq_notes/closures.html

Also read Crockford: http://javascript.crockford.com/

Content: Maybe this will change when Google releases its competing platform.

Author: nickb
Title: What is the Monkeysphere? (and the surprising implications for social nets)

Author: mariorz
Content: wow you're easily influenced by internet memes, I have trouble seeing how a site with a reasonably complete api is a walled garden.

Author: bokonist
Content:
+! for "JavaScript: The Definitive Guide"

Once you have learned javascript, DHTML: The Definitive Reference is a great desktop reference, although it's less important now that javascript libraries are so good.

Author: waleedka
Content:
I recommend "JavaScript: The Definitive Guide". I read a couple of pages in B&N to see if it was any good, and it paid for itself right there.

edit: Get the 5th Edition. See nickb's comment.

Author: Tichy
Content: Everytime I visit Wikipedia I contemplate writing a Greasemonkey script that would get rid of the "this article lacks citations" warning. I think they are definitely on the wrong track, hopefully they'll be able to change the direction again soon.

Author: davidw
Content:
> It might be fun to build you own CMS but, for many of us, could be a distraction from what we actually want to make.

Yes, my answer was a bit tongue-in-cheek. It's almost always better to see if there's some open source code you can build on.

Author: mechanical_fish
Content:
"Classic: a book which people praise and don't read."

http://www.twainquotes.com/Classic.html

In other words: Yes, in a world where every coder had an MIT degree, nobody would be especially impressed by DSLs.

Or maybe that wouldn't be enough. I've met several people who had SICP for their first-year programming class and did not like it at all.

Author: pius
Title: Ask YC Hackers: What's the best text for learning Javascript?
Content:
For a long time I've treated Javascript as a "second class citizen" and eschewed it in favor of Scheme, Java, Ruby, and (lately) Erlang. Now that I'm managing and coding with not just server-side hackers, but hardcore UX hackers as well, I'm realizing that I would like to become a solid Javascript developer as well.

What's the best Javascript text for an experienced developer?
